{{short description|Disproved conjecture in number theory}} '''Euler's conjecture''' is a disproved [[conjecture]] in [[mathematics]] related to [[Fermat's last theorem]]. It was proposed by [[Leonhard Euler]] in 1769. It states that for all [[integers]] {{math|''n''}} and {{math|''k''}} greater than 1, if the sum of {{math|''n''}} {{math|''k''}}th powers of positive integers is itself a {{math|''k''}}th power, then {{math|''n''}} is greater than or equal to {{math|''k''}}:
:{{math|{{SubSup|a|1|''k''}} + {{SubSup|a|2|''k''}} + ... + {{SubSup|a|''n''|''k''}} {{=}} ''b{{sup|k}}''}} ⇒ {{math|''n'' ≥ ''k''}}
The conjecture represents an attempt to generalize [[Fermat's last theorem]], which is the special case {{math|''n'' {{=}} 2}}: if {{math|{{SubSup|a|1|''k''}} + {{SubSup|a|2|''k''}} {{=}} ''b{{sup|k}}''}}, then {{math|2 ≥ ''k''}}.
Although the conjecture holds for the case {{math|''k'' {{=}} 3}} (which follows from Fermat's last theorem for the third powers), it was disproved for {{math|''k'' {{=}} 4}} and {{math|''k'' {{=}} 5}}. It is unknown whether the conjecture fails or holds for any value {{math|''k'' ≥ 6}}.
== Background == Euler was aware of the equality {{nowrap|59{{sup|4}} + 158{{sup|4}} {{=}} 133{{sup|4}} + 134{{sup|4}}}} involving sums of four fourth powers; this however is not a [[counterexample]] because no term is isolated on one side of the equation. He also provided a complete solution to the four cubes problem as in [[Plato's number]] {{nowrap|3{{sup|3}} + 4{{sup|3}} + 5{{sup|3}} {{=}} 6{{sup|3}}}} or the [[taxicab number]] 1729.<ref>{{cite book |editor-last=Dunham |editor-first=William |year=2007 |title=The Genius of Euler: Reflections on His Life and Work |publisher=The MAA |isbn=978-0-88385-558-4 |page=220 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=M4-zUnrSxNoC&pg=PA220}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last=Titus, III |first=Piezas |year=2005 |title=Euler's Extended Conjecture |url=http://www.oocities.org/titus_piezas/Equalsums.htm }}</ref> The general solution of the equation :<math>x_1^3+x_2^3=x_3^3+x_4^3</math> is :<math>x_1 = 1-(a-3b)(a^2+3b^2), \quad x_2 = (a+3b)(a^2+3b^2)-1</math> :<math>x_3 = (a+3b)-(a^2+3b^2)^2, \quad x_4 = (a^2+3b^2)^2-(a-3b)</math> where {{mvar|a}} and {{mvar|b}} are any integers.
== Counterexamples == Euler's conjecture was disproven by [[Leon J. Lander|L. J. Lander]] and [[Thomas Parkin (mathematician)|T. R. Parkin]] in 1966 when, through a direct computer search on a [[CDC 6600]], they found a counterexample for {{math|''k'' {{=}} 5}},<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Lander |first1=L. J. |last2=Parkin |first2=T. R. |year=1966 |title=Counterexample to Euler's conjecture on sums of like powers |journal=Bull. Amer. Math. Soc. |doi=10.1090/S0002-9904-1966-11654-3 |volume=72 |issue=6 |page=1079}}</ref> This was published in a paper comprising just two sentences.<ref name="Washietl">{{cite web |last1=Washietl |first1=Stefan |title=The Shortest Papers Ever Published |url=https://paperpile.com/blog/shortest-papers/ |accessdate=14 September 2019 |date=17 June 2016}}</ref> A total of three primitive (that is, in which the summands do not all have a common factor) counterexamples are known: ::{{math|27<sup>5</sup> + 84<sup>5</sup> + 110<sup>5</sup> + 133<sup>5</sup> {{=}} 144<sup>5</sup>}} (Lander & Parkin, 1966), ::{{math|(−220)<sup>5</sup> + 5027<sup>5</sup> + 6237<sup>5</sup> + {{val|14068}}<sup>5</sup> {{=}} {{val|14132}}<sup>5</sup>}} (Scher & Seidl, 1996), and ::{{math|55<sup>5</sup> + 3183<sup>5</sup> + {{val|28969}}<sup>5</sup> + {{val|85282}}<sup>5</sup> {{=}} {{val|85359}}<sup>5</sup>}} (Frye, 2004).
In 1986, [[Noam Elkies]] found a method to construct an infinite series of counterexamples for the {{math|''k'' {{=}} 4}} case.<ref name="Elkies1988">{{cite journal |last=Elkies |first=Noam |year=1988 |title=On ''A''<sup>4</sup> + ''B''<sup>4</sup> + ''C''<sup>4</sup> = ''D''<sup>4</sup> |journal=[[Mathematics of Computation]] |doi=10.1090/S0025-5718-1988-0930224-9 |mr=0930224 |jstor=2008781 |volume=51 |issue=184 |pages=825–835 |url=http://www.ams.org/journals/mcom/1988-51-184/S0025-5718-1988-0930224-9/S0025-5718-1988-0930224-9.pdf |format=PDF}}</ref> His smallest counterexample was ::{{math|{{val|2682440}}<sup>4</sup> + {{val|15365639}}<sup>4</sup> + {{val|18796760}}<sup>4</sup> {{=}} {{val|20615673}}<sup>4</sup>}}.
A particular case of Elkies' solutions can be reduced to the identity<ref>{{cite web |title=Elkies' ''a''<sup>4</sup>+''b''<sup>4</sup>+''c''<sup>4</sup> = ''d''<sup>4</sup> |url=https://groups.google.com/group/sci.math/browse_thread/thread/15beef75eaddcb1b?hl=en#}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Sums of Three Fourth Powers |url=http://sites.google.com/site/tpiezas/014}}</ref> ::{{math|(85''v''<sup>2</sup> + 484''v'' − 313)<sup>4</sup> + (68''v''<sup>2</sup> − 586''v'' + 10)<sup>4</sup> + (2''u'')<sup>4</sup> {{=}} (357''v''<sup>2</sup> − 204''v'' + 363)<sup>4</sup>}} where ::{{math|''u''<sup>2</sup> {{=}} {{val|22030}} + {{val|28849}}''v'' − {{val|56158}}''v''<sup>2</sup> + {{val|36941}}''v''<sup>3</sup> − {{val|31790}}''v''<sup>4</sup>}}. This is an [[elliptic curve]] with a [[rational point]] at {{math|''v''<sub>1</sub> {{=}} −{{sfrac|31|467}}}}. From this initial rational point, one can compute an infinite collection of others. Substituting {{math|''v''<sub>1</sub>}} into the identity and removing common factors gives the numerical example cited above.
In 1988, [[Roger Frye]] found the smallest possible counterexample ::{{math|{{val|95800}}<sup>4</sup> + {{val|217519}}<sup>4</sup> + {{val|414560}}<sup>4</sup> {{=}} {{val|422481}}<sup>4</sup>}} for {{math|''k'' {{=}} 4}} by a direct computer search using techniques suggested by Elkies. This solution is the only one with values of the variables below 1,000,000.<ref>{{citation | last = Frye | first = Roger E. | year = 1988 | title = Proceedings of Supercomputing 88, Vol.II: Science and Applications | contribution = Finding 95800<sup>4</sup> + 217519<sup>4</sup> + 414560<sup>4</sup> = 422481<sup>4</sup> on the Connection Machine | doi = 10.1109/SUPERC.1988.74138 | pages = 106–116}}</ref>
== Generalizations == [[File:Plato_number.svg|thumb|250px|One interpretation of Plato's number, {{nowrap|3³ + 4³ + 5³ {{=}} 6³}}]] {{main article|Lander, Parkin, and Selfridge conjecture}} In 1967, L. J. Lander, T. R. Parkin, and [[John Selfridge]] conjectured<ref name="autogenerated446">{{cite journal |last1=Lander |first1=L. J. |last2=Parkin |first2=T. R. |last3=Selfridge |first3=J. L. |year=1967 |title=A Survey of Equal Sums of Like Powers |journal=[[Mathematics of Computation]] |doi=10.1090/S0025-5718-1967-0222008-0 |jstor=2003249 |volume=21 |issue=99 |pages=446–459 }}</ref> that if :<math>\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_i^k = \sum_{j=1}^{m} b_j^k</math>, where {{math|''a<sub>i</sub>'' ≠ ''b<sub>j</sub>''}} are positive integers for all {{math|1 ≤ ''i'' ≤ ''n''}} and {{math|1 ≤ ''j'' ≤ ''m''}}, then {{math|''m'' + ''n'' ≥ ''k''}}. In the special case {{math|''m'' {{=}} 1}}, the conjecture states that if :<math>\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_i^k = b^k</math> (under the conditions given above) then {{math|''n'' ≥ ''k'' − 1}}.
The special case may be described as the problem of giving a [[partition (number theory)|partition]] of a perfect power into few like powers. For {{math|''k'' {{=}} 4, 5, 7, 8}} and {{math|''n'' {{=}} ''k''}} or {{math|''k'' − 1}}, there are many known solutions. Some of these are listed below. As of 2002, there are no solutions for <math>k=6</math> whose final term is ≤ 730000.<ref>Giovanni Resta and Jean-Charles Meyrignac (2002). [http://www.ams.org/journals/mcom/2003-72-242/S0025-5718-02-01445-X/S0025-5718-02-01445-X.pdf The Smallest Solutions to the Diophantine Equation <math>a^6+b^6+c^6+d^6+e^6=x^6+y^6</math>], Mathematics of Computation, v. 72, p. 1054 (See '''further work''' section).</ref>
==={{math|''k'' {{=}} 3}}=== ::{{nowrap|3{{sup|3}} + 4{{sup|3}} + 5{{sup|3}} {{=}} 6{{sup|3}}}} ([[Plato's number]] 216)
:This is the case ''a''=1, ''b''=0 of [[Srinivasa Ramanujan]]'s formula
::<math>(3a^2+5ab-5b^2)^3 + (4a^2-4ab+6b^2)^3 + (5a^2-5ab-3b^2)^3 = (6a^2-4ab+4b^2)^3 .</math> <ref name=Weisstein>[http://mathworld.wolfram.com/DiophantineEquation3rdPowers.html Math world : Diophantine Equation--3rd Powers]</ref>
:A cube as the sum of three cubes can also be parameterized as
::<math>a^3(a^3+b^3)^3 = b^3(a^3+b^3)^3+a^3(a^3-2b^3)^3+b^3(2a^3-b^3)^3</math>
:or as
::<math>a^3(a^3+2b^3)^3 = a^3(a^3-b^3)^3+b^3(a^3-b^3)^3+b^3(2a^3+b^3)^3.</math><ref name=Weisstein/>
:The number 2 100 000<sup>3</sup> can be expressed as the sum of three cubes in nine different ways.<ref name=Weisstein/>
==={{math|''k'' {{=}} 4}}=== ::{{math|{{val|95800}}<sup>4</sup> + {{val|217519}}<sup>4</sup> + {{val|414560}}<sup>4</sup> {{=}} {{val|422481}}<sup>4</sup>}} (R. Frye, 1988)<ref name="Elkies1988"/>
::{{math|30<sup>4</sup> + 120<sup>4</sup> + 272<sup>4</sup> + 315<sup>4</sup> {{=}} 353<sup>4</sup>}} (R. Norrie, 1911)<ref name="autogenerated446"/> This is the smallest solution to the problem by R. Norrie.
==={{math|''k'' {{=}} 5}}=== ::{{math|27<sup>5</sup> + 84<sup>5</sup> + 110<sup>5</sup> + 133<sup>5</sup> {{=}} 144<sup>5</sup>}} (Lander & Parkin, 1966)<ref name="mathologer">{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AO-W5aEJ3Wg |title=Euler's and Fermat's last theorems, the Simpsons and CDC6600 |author=Burkard Polster |date=March 24, 2018 |author-link=Burkard Polster |<!-- work=[[Mathologer]] -->type=video |accessdate=2018-03-24}}</ref>
::{{math|19<sup>5</sup> + 43<sup>5</sup> + 46<sup>5</sup> + 47<sup>5</sup> + 67<sup>5</sup> {{=}} 72<sup>5</sup>}} (Lander, Parkin, Selfridge, smallest, 1967)<ref name="autogenerated446"/>
::{{math|7<sup>5</sup> + 43<sup>5</sup> + 57<sup>5</sup> + 80<sup>5</sup> + 100<sup>5</sup> {{=}} 107<sup>5</sup>}} (Sastry, 1934, third smallest)<ref name="autogenerated446"/>
==={{math|''k'' {{=}} 7}}=== ::{{math|127<sup>7</sup> + 258<sup>7</sup> + 266<sup>7</sup> + 413<sup>7</sup> + 430<sup>7</sup> + 439<sup>7</sup> + 525<sup>7</sup> {{=}} 568<sup>7</sup>}} (M. Dodrill, 1999){{citation needed|date=October 2014}}
==={{math|''k'' {{=}} 8}}=== ::{{math|90<sup>8</sup> + 223<sup>8</sup> + 478<sup>8</sup> + 524<sup>8</sup> + 748<sup>8</sup> + 1088<sup>8</sup> + 1190<sup>8</sup> + 1324<sup>8</sup> {{=}} 1409<sup>8</sup>}} (S. Chase, 2000){{citation needed|date=October 2014}}
